ai-sn41:1.1.1_0: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
ai-sn41:1.1.2_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several senior mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them,
ai-sn41:1.1.3_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
ai-sn41:1.1.4_0: Some senior mendicants answered like this:
ai-sn41:1.1.5_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.1.6_0: But some senior mendicants answered like this:
ai-sn41:1.1.7_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’ mean the same thing; they differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.2.1_0: Now at that time the householder Citta had arrived at Migapathaka on some business.
ai-sn41:1.2.2_0: He heard about what those senior mendicants were discussing.
ai-sn41:1.2.3_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
ai-sn41:1.2.4_0: Some senior mendicants answered like this:
ai-sn41:1.2.5_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.2.6_0: But some senior mendicants answered like this:
ai-sn41:1.2.7_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’ mean the same thing; they differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.3.1_0: So he went up to them,
ai-sn41:1.3.1_2: He went to those senior mendicants, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,
ai-sn41:1.3.2_0: “Sirs, I heard that you were discussing whether the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’ differ in both meaning and phrasing, or whether they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.3.3_0: ‘Are the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
ai-sn41:1.3.4_0: But some senior mendicants answered like this:
ai-sn41:1.3.5_0: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.3.6_0: “Reverends, some senior mendicants answered like this: ‘These things are prone to being fettered’; they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-sn41:1.4.1_0: “Sirs, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things prone to being fettered’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-sn41:1.4.2_0: Well then, sirs, I shall give you a simile.
ai-sn41:1.4.3_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-sn41:1.4.4_0: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.
ai-sn41:1.4.5_0: Suppose someone were to say that
ai-sn41:1.4.6_0: the white ox, the yoke of the white ox, the white ox, and the yoke of the black ox.”
ai-sn41:1.4.8_0: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.
ai-sn41:1.4.9_0: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”
ai-sn41:1.4.10_0: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn41:1.4.11_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn41:1.4.15_0: The body is not the fetter of touches, nor touches,
ai-sn41:1.4.16_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn41:1.4.17_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn41:1.4.18_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”
ai-sn41:1.4.20_0: You call the word of the Buddha whose wisdom is deep.”
ai-sn41:1.4.21_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn41:2.1.1_0: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
ai-sn41:2.1.2_0: So he went up to them,
ai-sn41:2.1.2_2: He went to those senior mendicants, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,
ai-sn41:2.1.3_0: “Sirs, may the senior mendicants please accept my offering of tomorrow’s meal.”
ai-sn41:2.1.4_0: And they accepted by remaining silent.
ai-sn41:2.1.5_0: Knowing that the senior mendicants had consented, Citta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled them, keeping them on his right, before leaving.

ai-sn41:2.2.3_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”
ai-sn41:2.2.4_0: When he said this, Senior kept silent.
ai-sn41:2.2.6_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.
ai-sn41:2.2.7_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”
ai-sn41:2.2.9_0: And for a third time, Citta said to him:
ai-sn41:2.2.10_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.
ai-sn41:2.2.11_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”
ai-sn41:2.2.12_0: And for a third time, Senior kept silent.
ai-sn41:2.3.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Isidatta was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.
ai-sn41:2.3.2_0: Then Isidatta said to Venerable Isidatta,
ai-sn41:2.3.3_0: “Sir, I wish to ask you for Citta for forgiveness.
ai-sn41:2.3.4_0: “Reverend Isidatta, you’re acting for your mind.”
ai-sn41:2.3.7_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?’”
ai-sn41:2.3.9_0: “This is the diversity of elements spoken of by the Buddha.
ai-sn41:2.3.10_0: The eye element, the sights element, the eye consciousness element ...
ai-sn41:2.3.11_0: the mind, thoughts, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn41:2.3.12_0: That’s how the diversity of elements defined by the Buddha.”
ai-sn41:2.4.1_0: Then Citta the householder approved and agreed with what Venerable Isidatta said.
ai-sn41:2.4.2_0: After the Buddha had eaten, the senior monks got up from their seats and left.
ai-sn41:2.4.3_0: Then Venerable Isidatta said to Venerable Isidatta,
ai-sn41:2.4.4_0: “Isidatta, it’s good that you felt inspired to answer that question, because I didn’t.
ai-sn41:2.4.5_0: So, reverends, when Isidatta comes to see such a question, it would occur to him.”

ai-sn41:3.2.3_0: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-sn41:3.2.4_0: And these two convictions were born in to Brahmā.
ai-sn41:3.2.5_0: When what exists do these views come to be? When what doesn’t exist do these views not come to be?”
ai-sn41:3.3.1_0: When he said this, Senior kept silent.

ai-sn41:3.3.4_0: “Sir, there are many different views that arise in the world. ...

ai-sn41:3.4.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Isidatta was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.
ai-sn41:3.4.2_0: Then Isidatta said to Venerable Isidatta,
ai-sn41:3.4.3_0: “Sir, I wish to ask you for Citta for forgiveness.
ai-sn41:3.4.4_0: “Reverend Isidatta, you’re acting for your mind.”
ai-sn41:3.4.6_0: ‘Sir, there are many different views that arise in the world. ...
ai-sn41:3.4.8_0: When what exists do these views come to be? When what doesn’t exist do these views not come to be?’’
ai-sn41:3.4.10_0: “Householder, there are many different views that arise in the world. For example:
ai-sn41:3.4.11_0: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-sn41:3.4.12_0: And these two convictions were born in to Brahmā.
ai-sn41:3.4.13_0: These views come to be when identity view exists. When identity view does not exist they do not come to be.”
ai-sn41:3.5.1_0: “But sir, how does identity view come about?”
ai-sn41:3.5.2_0: “Householder, take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn41:3.5.3_0: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn41:3.5.7_0: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-sn41:3.5.8_0: That’s how identity view comes about.”
ai-sn41:3.6.1_0: “But sir, how does identity view not come about?”
ai-sn41:3.6.2_0: “It’s when an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.
ai-sn41:3.6.3_0: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
ai-sn41:3.6.5_0: They don’t regard perception as self ...
ai-sn41:3.6.6_0: They don’t regard choices as self ...
ai-sn41:3.6.7_0: They don’t regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
ai-sn41:3.6.8_0: That’s how identity view does not come about.”
ai-sn41:3.7.3_0: “Sir, there’s a friend of mine called Isidatta who I’ve never met. He’s gone forth from a good family in Avanti.
ai-sn41:3.7.6_0: “Sir, where is that venerable now staying?”
ai-sn41:3.7.7_0: When he said this, Isidatta kept silent.
ai-sn41:3.7.10_0: “Sir, I hope Venerable Isidatta is happy here in Macchikāsaṇḍa,
ai-sn41:3.7.12_0: I’ll make sure that Venerable Isidatta is provided with robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
ai-sn41:3.7.13_0: “That’s good of you to say, householder.”
ai-sn41:3.8.1_0: Then Citta the householder approved and agreed with what Venerable Isidatta said.

ai-sn41:3.8.3_0: Then Venerable Isidatta said to Venerable Isidatta,

ai-sn41:3.8.5_0: that you speak such question me.

ai-sn41:4.2.1_0: Then Citta served and satisfied the senior mendicants with his own hands with delicious milk-rice made with ghee.

ai-sn41:4.2.3_0: Citta instructed that the remainder of the food be distributed, then followed behind the senior mendicants.
ai-sn41:4.2.4_0: Now at that time the heat was sweltering.
ai-sn41:4.2.5_0: And those senior mendicants walked along as if their bodies were melting, as happens after a meal.
ai-sn41:4.3.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Mahaka was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.
ai-sn41:4.3.2_0: Then Venerable Mahaka said to the senior venerable,
ai-sn41:4.3.3_0: “Wouldn’t it be nice, sir, if a cool wind blew, a cloud canopy formed, and a gentle rain drizzled down?”
ai-sn41:4.4.1_0: “It would indeed be nice, Reverend Mahaka.”
ai-sn41:4.4.2_0: Then Mahaka used his psychic power to will that a cool wind would blow, a cloud canopy would form, and a gentle rain would drizzle down.
ai-sn41:4.4.4_0: “The most junior mendicant in this Saṅgha has such psychic power!”
ai-sn41:4.4.5_0: When they reached the monastery, Mahaka said to the senior venerable,
ai-sn41:4.4.10_0: Then the senior mendicants entered their dwellings,
ai-sn41:4.4.11_0: and Mahaka entered his own dwelling.
ai-sn41:4.5.1_0: Then Citta went up to Mahaka,
ai-sn41:4.5.2_0: “Sir, please show me a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.”
ai-sn41:4.5.3_0: “Well, then, householder, place your upper robe on the porch and spread a handful of grass on it.”
ai-sn41:4.5.4_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Citta, and did as he was asked.
ai-sn41:4.5.5_0: Mahaka entered his dwelling and latched the door. Then he used his psychic power to will that a flame shoot out through the keyhole and the chink in the door, and it burned up the grass but not the upper robe.
ai-sn41:4.5.6_0: Then Citta shook out his upper robe and stood to one side, shocked and awestruck.

ai-sn41:5.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Kāmabhū was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
ai-sn41:5.1.2_0: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Kāmabhū,
ai-sn41:5.4.1_0: How should we see the detailed meaning of this brief statement?”
ai-sn41:5.4.2_0: “Sir, was this spoken by the Buddha?”
ai-sn41:5.4.4_0: “Well then, sir, please wait a moment while I consider the meaning of this.”
ai-sn41:5.4.5_0: Then after a short silence Citta said to Kāmabhū:
ai-sn41:5.5.1_0: “Sir, ‘flawless wheel’ is a term for ethics.
ai-sn41:5.5.2_0: ‘White canopy’ is a term for freedom.
ai-sn41:5.5.3_0: ‘One spoke’ is a term for mindfulness.
ai-sn41:5.5.4_0: ‘Rolls on’ is a term for going forward and coming back.
ai-sn41:5.5.5_0: ‘Chariot’ is a term for this body made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
ai-sn41:5.5.6_0: Greed, hate, and delusion are troubles.
ai-sn41:5.5.7_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:5.5.8_0: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is called ‘untroubled’.
ai-sn41:5.5.9_0: ‘The one who comes’ is a term for the perfected one.
ai-sn41:5.5.11_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:5.5.12_0: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is said to have ‘cut the stream’.
ai-sn41:5.5.13_0: Greed, hate, and delusion are bonds.
ai-sn41:5.5.14_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:5.5.15_0: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is called ‘unbound’.
ai-sn41:5.5.16_0: So, sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief:
ai-sn41:5.7.1_0: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
ai-sn41:5.7.3_0: You call the word of the Buddha whose wisdom is deep.”
ai-sn41:6.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Kāmabhū was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
ai-sn41:6.1.2_0: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Kāmabhū,
ai-sn41:6.1.2_1: he had sat down at a distance.
ai-sn41:6.1.5_0: Choices by way of body, speech, and mind.”
ai-sn41:6.1.6_0: Saying “Good, sir,”, Citta approved and agreed with what Venerable Kāmabhū said. Then he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.1.7_0: “But sir, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”
ai-sn41:6.1.8_0: “Breathing is a physical process. Placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes. Perception and feeling are mental processes.”
ai-sn41:6.2.1_0: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.2.2_0: “But sir, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected verbal processes? Why are perception and feeling mental processes?”
ai-sn41:6.2.3_0: “Breathing is physical. It’s tied up with the body, that’s why breathing is a physical process.
ai-sn41:6.2.4_0: First you place the mind and keep it connected, then you break into speech. That’s why placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes.
ai-sn41:6.2.5_1: They’re tied up with the mind, that’s why perception and feeling are mental processes.”
ai-sn41:6.3.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.3.2_0: “But sir, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-sn41:6.3.3_0: “A mendicant who is entering such an attainment does not think:
ai-sn41:6.3.4_0: ‘I will enter the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am entering the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have entered the cessation of perception and feeling.’
ai-sn41:6.3.5_0: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”
ai-sn41:6.4.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.4.2_0: “But sir, which cease first for a mendicant who is entering the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”
ai-sn41:6.4.3_0: “Verbal processes cease first, then physical, then mental.”
ai-sn41:6.5.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.5.2_0: “What’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-sn41:6.5.3_0: “When someone dies, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled; their vitality is spent; their warmth is dissipated; and their faculties have disintegrated.
ai-sn41:6.5.4_0: When a mendicant has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled. But their vitality is not spent; their warmth is not dissipated; and their faculties are very clear.
ai-sn41:6.5.5_0: That’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling.”
ai-sn41:6.6.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.6.2_0: “But sir, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-sn41:6.6.3_0: “A mendicant who is emerging from such an attainment does not think:
ai-sn41:6.6.4_0: ‘I will emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling.’
ai-sn41:6.6.5_0: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”
ai-sn41:6.7.1_0: Saying “Good, sir, I asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.7.2_0: “But sir, which arise first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”
ai-sn41:6.7.3_0: “Mental processes arise first, then physical, then verbal.”
ai-sn41:6.8.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.8.2_0: “But sir, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”
ai-sn41:6.9.1_0: Saying “Good, good,” he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.9.2_0: “But sir, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, what does their mind slant, slope, and incline to?”
ai-sn41:6.9.3_0: “Their mind slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion.”
ai-sn41:6.10.1_0: Saying “Good, sir,”, Citta approved and agreed with what Venerable Kāmabhū said. Then he asked another question:
ai-sn41:6.10.2_0: “But sir, how many things are helpful for attaining the cessation of perception and feeling?”
ai-sn41:6.10.3_0: “Well, householder, you’ve finally asked what you should have asked first!
ai-sn41:6.10.5_0: Two things are helpful for attaining the cessation of perception and feeling:
ai-sn41:7.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Godatta was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
ai-sn41:7.1.2_0: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Godatta,
ai-sn41:7.1.2_1: bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-sn41:7.1.3_0: “Householder, the limitless release of the heart, and the release of the heart through nothingness, and the release of the heart through emptiness, and the signless release of the heart: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
ai-sn41:7.1.4_0: “Sir, there is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-sn41:7.1.5_0: But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.
ai-sn41:7.2.1_0: “And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?
ai-sn41:7.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-sn41:7.2.2_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-sn41:7.2.3_0: I meditate spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, I spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-sn41:7.2.4_0: Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing ...
ai-sn41:7.2.5_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-sn41:7.2.6_0: This is called the limitless release of the heart.
ai-sn41:7.3.1_0: And what is the release of the heart through nothingness?
ai-sn41:7.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
ai-sn41:7.3.3_0: This is called the release of the heart through nothingness.
ai-sn41:7.4.1_0: And what is the release of the heart through emptiness?
ai-sn41:7.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
ai-sn41:7.4.3_0: ‘This field is empty of self or what belongs to self.’
ai-sn41:7.4.4_0: This is called the release of the heart through emptiness.
ai-sn41:7.5.1_0: And what is the signless heart’s release?
ai-sn41:7.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.
ai-sn41:7.5.3_0: This is called the signless release of the heart.
ai-sn41:7.5.4_0: This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-sn41:7.6.1_0: And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?
ai-sn41:7.6.2_0: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits.
ai-sn41:7.6.3_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:7.6.4_0: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of limitless release of the heart.
ai-sn41:7.6.5_0: But the unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn41:7.6.6_0: Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something.
ai-sn41:7.6.7_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:7.6.8_0: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of release of the heart through nothingness.
ai-sn41:7.6.9_0: But the unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn41:7.6.10_0: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs.
ai-sn41:7.6.11_0: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn41:7.6.12_0: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of signless release of the heart.
ai-sn41:7.6.13_0: But the unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-sn41:7.6.14_0: This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-sn41:7.6.16_0: You call the word of the Buddha whose wisdom is deep.”
ai-sn41:8.1.1_0: Now at that time Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta had arrived at Macchikāsaṇḍa together with a large assembly of Jain ascetics.
ai-sn41:8.1.3_0: Together with several lay followers, he went up to Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta and Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta.
ai-sn41:8.1.4_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn41:8.1.5_0: “Householder, do you have faith in the ascetic Gotama’s claim that
ai-sn41:8.1.6_0: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected?”
ai-sn41:8.2.1_0: “Sir, in this case I don’t rely on faith in the Buddha’s claim that
ai-sn41:8.2.2_0: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected?”
ai-sn41:8.2.3_0: When he said this, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta looked up at his assembly and said,
ai-sn41:8.2.4_0: “See, good sirs, how straightforward this householder Citta is! He’s not devious or deceitful at all. To imagine that you can stop placing the mind and keeping it connected would be like imagining that you can catch the wind in a net, or dam the Ganges river with your own hand.”
ai-sn41:8.3.3_0: “Knowledge is definitely better than faith, householder.”
ai-sn41:8.3.4_0: “Well sir, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn41:8.3.5_0: And whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled ...
ai-sn41:8.3.5_1: I enter and remain in the second absorption.
ai-sn41:8.3.6_0: And whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture ... I enter and remain in the third absorption.
ai-sn41:8.3.7_0: And whenever I want, giving up pleasure and pain ...
ai-sn41:8.3.7_1: enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
ai-sn41:8.3.8_0: And so, sir, since I know and see like this, why should I rely on faith in another ascetic or brahmin who claims that
ai-sn41:8.3.9_0: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected?”
ai-sn41:8.4.1_0: When he said this, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta looked askance at his own assembly and said,
ai-sn41:8.4.2_0: “See, good sirs, how crooked this householder Citta is! He’s so devious and deceitful!”
ai-sn41:8.5.1_0: “Sir, just now I understood you to say:
ai-sn41:8.5.2_0: ‘See, good sirs, how straightforward this householder Citta is! He’s not devious or deceitful at all.’
ai-sn41:8.5.3_0: But then I understood you to say:
ai-sn41:8.5.4_0: ‘See, good sirs, how crooked this householder Citta is! He’s so devious and deceitful!’
ai-sn41:8.5.5_0: If your first statement is wrong, the second is true.
ai-sn41:8.5.6_0: If your first statement is wrong, the second is true.
ai-sn41:8.5.7_0: And there are these ten legitimate questions that come to be.
ai-sn41:8.5.8_0: When you understand what they mean, then, together with your assembly of Jain ascetics, you can rebut me.
ai-sn41:8.5.9_0: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer. Two ... three ... four ... five ... six ... seven ... eight ... nine ... ten things: question, summary, and answer.’”
ai-sn41:8.5.10_0: two questions: questions, passage for recitation, and answer.
ai-sn41:8.5.11_0: There are three recitations: question, and answer.
ai-sn41:8.5.12_0: There are four questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.
ai-sn41:8.5.15_0: Seven questions: questions, seven passage for recitation, and answer.
ai-sn41:8.5.16_0: Eight questions: questions, and answer eight questions.
ai-sn41:8.5.17_0: Nine questions, passage for recitation, and answer.
ai-sn41:8.5.18_0: Ten questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.”
ai-sn41:8.5.19_0: Then Citta got up from his seat and left without asking Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta these ten legitimate questions.
ai-sn41:9.1.1_0: Now at that time the naked ascetic Kassapa, who in lay life was an old friend of Citta, had arrived at Macchikāsaṇḍa.
ai-sn41:9.1.3_0: So he went to see him.
ai-sn41:9.1.4_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn41:9.1.5_0: “Sir, Kassapa, how long has it been since you went forth?”
ai-sn41:9.1.7_0: “But sir, in these thirty years have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease?”
ai-sn41:9.1.8_0: “I have no such achievement, householder, only nakedness, baldness, and pokes in the buttocks.”
ai-sn41:9.1.11_0: how well explained the teaching is. For in thirty years you have achieved no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, no meditation at ease, only nakedness, baldness, and pokes in the buttocks.”
ai-sn41:9.2.1_0: “But householder, how long have you been a lay follower?”
ai-sn41:9.2.3_0: “But householder, in these thirty years have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease?”
ai-sn41:9.2.5_0: For whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn41:9.2.6_0: And whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled ...
ai-sn41:9.2.6_1: I enter and remain in the second absorption.
ai-sn41:9.2.7_0: And whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture ... I enter and remain in the third absorption.
ai-sn41:9.2.8_0: And whenever I want, giving up pleasure and pain ... I enter and remain in the fourth absorption.
ai-sn41:9.2.9_0: But sir, if I were to die first, I would say:
ai-sn41:9.2.10_0: ‘The householder Citta is bound by no fetter that might return him to this world.’”
ai-sn41:9.2.11_0: When this was said, Kassapa said to Citta,
ai-sn41:9.2.12_0: “The great power and might of the Buddha
ai-sn41:9.2.13_0: How well explained the teaching and training in that they have achieved superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
ai-sn41:9.2.14_0: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
ai-sn41:9.3.1_0: Then Citta the householder took the naked ascetic Kassapa to see the senior mendicants,
ai-sn41:9.3.2_0: “Sirs, this is the naked ascetic Kassapa, who in lay life was an old friend of mine.
ai-sn41:9.3.3_0: May the senior monks give him the going forth, the ordination.
ai-sn41:9.3.4_0: I’ll make sure that he’s provided with robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
ai-sn41:9.3.5_0: And the naked ascetic Kassapa received the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training.
ai-sn41:9.3.6_0: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn41:9.3.7_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn41:9.3.8_0: And Venerable Kassapa became one of the perfected.
ai-sn41:10.1.1_0: Now at that time the householder Citta was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn41:10.1.2_0: Then several deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees came together and said to Citta,
ai-sn41:10.1.3_0: “Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!”
ai-sn41:10.2.1_0: When they said this, Citta said to them,
ai-sn41:10.2.2_0: “That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!”
ai-sn41:10.2.3_0: When he said this, his friends and colleagues, relatives and family members said,
ai-sn41:10.2.5_0: “What have I said that makes you say that?”
ai-sn41:10.2.8_0: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”
ai-sn41:10.2.9_0: “Oh, well, that’s because the deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees said to me:
ai-sn41:10.2.10_0: ‘Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!’
ai-sn41:10.2.12_0: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”
ai-sn41:10.2.13_0: “But what reason do they see for saying that to you?”
ai-sn41:10.2.14_0: ‘Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!’”
ai-sn41:10.2.16_0: ‘This householder Citta is ethical, of good character.
ai-sn41:10.2.17_0: If he makes a wish to
ai-sn41:10.2.18_0: become a wheel-turning monarch in the future, his heart’s wish will succeed because of the purity of his ethics. And then as a proper, principled king he will provide proper spirit-offerings.’
ai-sn41:10.2.19_0: For this reason, they see what reasons to fall apart from the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees said to him,
ai-sn41:10.2.20_0: ‘Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!’
ai-sn41:10.2.22_0: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”
ai-sn41:10.3.3_0: We will have experiential confidence in the Buddha:
ai-sn41:10.3.4_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
ai-sn41:10.3.5_0: We will have experiential confidence in the teaching:
ai-sn41:10.3.6_0: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
ai-sn41:10.3.7_0: We will have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:
ai-sn41:10.3.8_0: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, methodical, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
ai-sn41:10.3.9_0: And we will share without reservation all the gifts available to give in our family with those who are ethical and of good character.”
ai-sn41:10.3.10_0: Then, after Citta had encouraged his friends and colleagues, relatives and family members in the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, and generosity, he passed away.
ai-sn41:10.3.12_0: The first sub-chapter on Citta is finished.
ai-sn41:10.4.5_0: The Linked Discourses on Citta the Householder are complete.
